fields.description:
I'm sure there are many pipeline users using maven to deploy to aws. It\\
would be nice if there was a maven+awscli image made available from\\
pipelines for us to use.
fields.summary: Add maven and awscli image for pipelines
User Error on Bitbucket Pipelines

fields.description:
When a user is added to a Team via user groups, they're granted with only permission to access the repository. The user is not granted with Team permissions (Admin or Create repository).

With this configuration, the user is not able to see which Team Account that they have access to. The user can however, access and view the repository.

This however, would affect users that would want to configure a CI specific user in Jenkins whereby Jenkins wouldn't be able to know which Team does the repository belong to while configuring it. This is because the user is not considered part of the team eventhough they have access to the Team Repositories via user group access.

_Sample Screenshot_ - Its not able to show the Team Account at "Which team does this repository belong to". It displays the authenticated account but not the Team Account.

!3276594126-team_selection.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Unable to see which Team a user belongs to if there is no Team Admin or Create repo permission

fields.description: Recent Activity pane displays 'Repo activity is currently unavailable' on overview screen. RSS feed works.
fields.summary: Recent Activity - Repo activity is currently unavailable

fields.description:
Our CI tool uses the bitbucket v2 API to automatically create webhooks for projects.

Today, we suddenly started getting the following response to our POST requests:

{"type": "error", "error": {"fields": {"history_enabled": ["This field may not be null."]}, "message": "Bad request"}}

There is no mention of this field in the API documentation or the webhook documentation, though I do see the box in the UI that I assume it corresponds to.  Was this field recently made required on accident?
fields.summary: history_enabled suddenly a required field in webhook post

fields.description: Right now there there is no way to speed up LFS transactions used in Pipelines. I'd be nice if we had some media adapter capability
fields.summary: Speed up LFS operations with media adapater in Pipelines

fields.description:
I use BitBucket for projects within several organizations. It would be very helpful to provide a "single-click switch account" option.

As it stands, I must logout of one account, then log in to another account. When I may do this a dozen times in a single day it becomes an annoyance.
fields.summary: Single-Click Switch Accounts

fields.description:
I have a repo that isn't getting past the {{Build setup}} stage. I've tried a few times, with the same commit and a trivial edit / recommit. No luck or feedback.

In this case, I happen to have a second repo that I _can_ redeploy. The Pipelines setup is qualitatively identical (basically only the names and AWS credentials differ). The code in the repos is basically identical, AFAIK, up to configuration differences within the things that actually run on the instances.
fields.summary: Are some pipelines down? Stuck in Build Setup stage with no feedback

fields.description:
Hi Support,

Can you please check why pipeline stuck at the Build setup step:

https://bitbucket.org/bookease/apps/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/324 ?
fields.summary: Pipeline stuck at Build Setup step

fields.description:
It can be cumbersome and easy to forget to constantly add  the "[skip ci]" tag to the git commit message if  we want to not trigger the commit build in Pipelines.

There should be a new option in the UI to allow us to perform the exact thing.
fields.summary: Add a new option to disable auto build in every commit.

fields.description: It would be great if we can label artifacts with specified names instead of just showing the file path pattern to make it easier for us to identify them.
fields.summary: Please allow artifacts to be labelled with specified names.

fields.description:
The Pipelines artifacts downloaded as a tar.gz files have confusing long file names.

Please use shorter and\\
simpler names, something like "artifact04.1 2018-10-25 ProjectName.tar.gz".\\
"04" is the build number and ".1" is the first artifact in the list.
fields.summary: Human understandable name for tar of artifacts

fields.description:
Please show the artifacts on the pipelines page, for example at\\
https://bitbucket.org/user/project/addon/pipelines/home#!/results/5 . When\\
the user clicks on "Artifacts" at the top of the page, all the artifacts\\
should be displayed within the page, instead of just having download links.
fields.summary: Allow pipelines artifacts to be shown on the Pipelines Page.

fields.description:
Some customers will experience timeout errors or\\
"Unable to Merge\\
an error occurred saving this Pull request"\\
when trying to merge Pull Request using Bitbucket UI

As a workaround until this issue with timeout is resolved,  users can use API call to merge the PR:\\
https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories/%7Busername%7D/%7Brepo_slug%7D/pullrequests/%7Bpull_request_id%7D/merge
fields.summary: When merging Pull request using UI getting " Unable to merge" (BBCDEV-11112)

fields.description:
It would be useful to have an {{init:}} block where environment variables can be set from within {{bitbucket-pipelines.yml}}.

An example use case would be to set up globals for the repo. This way, I can do something like declare the project name, docker image name, and so on within the file rather than having to do so through the bitbucket UI which makes it a bit easier to set up new builds along with new projects. This is particularly useful when working in a microservice architecture and services are being stood up somewhat rapidly and even changing just as rapidly.

Here's a sample pipeline config for one of my projects. Notice in the artifacts area, I have to hardcode the path because I don't have an environment variable set, and I don't really have an opportunity to run the export command to set it like I do for the script areas. This could be more genericized, had i had the option.

{code}
#!yaml
image: microsoft/dotnet:sdk

.set_environment: &setenv |
  export PROJECT_NAME=DAS.Data.ETL.HomeNet
  export DOCKER_IMAGE=gcr.io/dasplatform-production/das/data.etl.homenet
  export DEPLOYMENT_NAME=etl-homenet

.gcloud_auth: &gcloudAuth |
  echo $GCP_CREDS_DEV | base64 --decode --ignore-garbage > ./gcloud-api-key.json
  gcloud auth activate-service-account --key-file gcloud-api-key.json
  gcloud auth configure-docker --quiet
  gcloud config set project $GCP_PROJECT
  gcloud container clusters get-credentials reticle --region us-central1-a

pipelines:
  default:
    - step: &buildtest
        name: Build and Unit Test
        caches:
          - dotnetcore
        artifacts:
          - src/**/bin/Release/**.nupkg
        script:           
          - dotnet restore src -s $NUGET_SOURCE -s https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json
          - dotnet build src -c Release -p:BuildNumber=$BITBUCKET_BUILD_NUMBER
          - dotnet tool install -g trx2junit
          - export PATH="$PATH:/root/.dotnet/tools"
          - |
                function convert_tests {
                  ls test-results/*.trx | xargs trx2junit
                  rm test-results/*.trx
                }
                trap convert_tests EXIT
          - dotnet vstest src/**/bin/Release/**/**.Tests.dll --logger:trx --ResultsDirectory:test-results            
  branches:
    dev:
      - parallel:
        - step: *buildtest
        - step:
            name: Publish netcore artifacts
            artifacts:              
              - src/DAS.Data.ETL.HomeNet/out/**              
            script:
              - *setenv
              - dotnet restore src -s $NUGET_SOURCE -s https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json
              - dotnet publish src/$PROJECT_NAME/$PROJECT_NAME.csproj -c Release -o out           
      - step:
          name: Build and push docker image
          image: google/cloud-sdk:latest
          script:
            - *setenv            
            - *gcloudAuth
            - docker build -t $DOCKER_IMAGE:$BITBUCKET_COMMIT src/$PROJECT_NAME/ 
            - docker push $DOCKER_IMAGE
          services:
            - docker
      - step:
          name: Deploy to Dev
          deployment: test
          image: google/cloud-sdk:latest
          script:
            - *setenv
            - *gcloudAuth
            - kubectl apply -f kube/dev.yaml # this is where helm could be nice
            - kubectl set image -n dev deploy/$DEPLOYMENT_NAME $DEPLOYMENT_NAME=$DOCKER_IMAGE:$BITBUCKET_COMMIT
    master:
      # these can't be run in parallel because the nuget publish needs the artifacts of the first step
      - step: *buildtest      
      - step:
          name: Publish netcore artifacts
          artifacts:
            - src/DAS.Data.ETL.HomeNet/out/**              
          script:
            - *setenv
            - dotnet restore src -s $NUGET_SOURCE -s https://api.nuget.org/v3/index.json
            - dotnet publish src/$PROJECT_NAME/$PROJECT_NAME.csproj -c Release -o out      
            - dotnet nuget push src/**/bin/Release/**.nupkg -s $NUGET_SOURCE  
      - step:
          name: Build and push docker image
          image: google/cloud-sdk:latest
          script: # master builds also tag latest
            - *setenv            
            - *gcloudAuth
            - docker build -t $DOCKER_IMAGE:$BITBUCKET_COMMIT src/$PROJECT_NAME/
            - docker tag $DOCKER_IMAGE:$BITBUCKET_COMMIT $DOCKER_IMAGE:latest
            - docker push $DOCKER_IMAGE:$BITBUCKET_COMMIT
            - docker push $DOCKER_IMAGE:latest
          services:
            - docker       
      - step:
          name: Deploy to Staging/QA
          deployment: staging
          image: google/cloud-sdk:latest
          script: 
            # this can't really be tested well in QA so for now, it goes straight from dev to prod
            - echo 'There is no staging environment at this time. This is just here to enforce the standard pipeline.' 
      - step:
          name: Deploy to Production
          deployment: production
          trigger: manual
          image: google/cloud-sdk:latest
          script:
            - *setenv
            - *gcloudAuth
            - kubectl apply -f kube/prod.yaml # this is where helm could be nice
            - kubectl set image -n prod deploy/$DEPLOYMENT_NAME $DEPLOYMENT_NAME=$DOCKER_IMAGE:$BITBUCKET_COMMIT

{code}
fields.summary: Setup environment variables in bitbucket-pipelines.yml

In Bitbucket however, when I try to clone a repository it doesn't seem to accept the same password as I get an error.\\

fields.description:
Currently there is no option to run a pipeline only once at a future date/time via the scheduler. You have to set a schedule and remember to delete it after the pipeline has been triggered. This could be useful if you want to merge a pull request ahead of time but deploy at later date/time only once. Example: After hours deployment.

Adding a checkbox with "Run Once" option on the scheduler menu could be a good way to implement this.
fields.summary: Configure scheduled pipeline to run only once

fields.description: Right now we give 429 errors via the API when a customer is rate limited. Might be a good idea to also give a banner warning with a link to our API/rate limiting documentation as well.
fields.summary: If account is being rate limited, give notice via UI

fields.summary: Typing [ in user group repositories search bar will cause the page to load an error page

fields.description:
h2. Problem Definition
BBC repository has a hard limit of its size.\\
https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/what-kind-of-limits-do-you-have-on-repository-file-size-273877699.html

However, it's unclear if the total size of image files attached to Issue Tracker depends on the hard limit of its repository or has a dedicated limit.

h2. Suggested Solution
Update the document to clarify if it depends on its repository's size limit or has a dedicated limit.\\
https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/issue-trackers-221449750.html

h2. Workaround
None.
fields.summary: Clarify if the total size of attachments in Issue Tracker has a dedicated limit

It appears that Bitbucket's rendering of README.md files is adding quote characters before and after selectors to markdown blockquotes ({{>}}).\\
Also, it seems this only happens once the user is logged in as shown below.\\
!1100393763-Pasted_Image_29_10_18_16_02.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Markdown quoted text rendering with double quotes. - Customer's behalf

fields.description:
Hello,\\
We noticed that one of the non-project member ( who do not have access to bitbucket repo but have access to Jira ) is able to commit code to repository.

In the repository commits, he is referred as "Author not mapped to bitbucket user".

Please let us know how to restrict such commits ?

Thanks,\\
Kumaresan.
fields.summary: Non-Project member commiting code to repository

fields.description:
I have a new piece of python code at lines 982-991 (of 1276 lines in total), with an highlight/indication to where it is inserted in the previous version of the code (so between lines 981 and 982 in this case). When scrolling down, the green highlighting between the two columns that contain the line numbers ('GH') moves up with the block of new code, but only until line 1001 appears at the bottom. From then on, GH stays put while the highlighted piece of new code moves up. When line 1011 or 1012 reaches the top of the window, GH disappears. When I scroll down again, GH only reappears (and reconnects with the highlighted piece of new code) when line 1001 has disappeared from the window.\\
Google Chrome version 69.0.3497.100 (Official Build) (64-bit) on Fedora 28, Gnome 3.28.2.
fields.summary: Green 'diff pointer' stays put when scrolling down (past line 1000) on side-by-side view

fields.description:
Dear Attlassian,

I'm trying to add the following rsa key at https://bitbucket.org/account/user/mr_big/ssh-keys/ page, but I get the error "That SSH key is invalid."

{code}
ssh-rsa AAAAB3NzaC1yc2EAAAAFALVoPe0AAACBANGt8z5XY26IqSBu/w/yGFvWKBCo+jFdBovDr0B9e7FyAhQZhis2x6hGtBkm+WJqTXzBZQX2LGBC7gDZjMdtttBxWUzt5nECMWodprtXpQLa1I97K7FofxxcYdlo1eCeJW0p9KdlLXMgTvCD+0Vo9WW9wR8Wzld18btghgZ3UxWn
{code}

The response "That SSH key is invalid" is obviously not true, I'm using the same key at a dozens of site without problem, and I was using it at bitbucket before 2016 as well.

Sadly it seems like Bitbucket decided to not support rsa keys shorter than 2048bits. The above key is a 1024 bit key (generated by a hardware token).

Expected result:

the site should tell the user, that the rsa key is valid, but not long enough, so it is rejected on administrative grounds.
fields.summary: Can't add valid RSA key, marked as "invalid"

fields.description:
[This ticket is a follow up of a change in 2016. Original ticket: BBS-35401]

Dear Atlassian,

Bitbucket SSH server drop the connection in some cases when an unsupported RSA public key is offered for authentication.

I normally use a hardware token with a 1024bit rsa key. This key size is not supported by bitbucket since 2016, so I generate a software token for bitbucket access.

Unfortunately when my hardware key precedes the software key at the authentication then bitbucket disconnects and doesn't wait for the software key to offered.

h1. Details
This is what happens when the 1024bit key is offered first:

{code}
#!bash

mrbig@toodark:~ $ ssh-add -l
1024 a7:83:14:47:7b:a1:ae:45:6b:c9:be:01:5c:74:7d:20 Private Key (RSA1)
1024 c6:f4:4b:b9:64:59:00:1a:fd:3c:ea:0a:fe:dd:4f:0a Private Key (RSA)
2048 9c:53:e4:1b:07:9d:b6:50:cc:4a:09:a4:41:f5:93:5a .ssh/id_rsa_bitbucket (RSA)

mrbig@toodark:~ $ ssh -v -T git@bitbucket.org
OpenSSH_5.1p1 Debian-6, OpenSSL 0.9.8m 25 Feb 2010
debug1: Reading configuration data /home/mrbig/.ssh/config
debug1: Applying options for *
debug1: Reading configuration data /etc/ssh/ssh_config
debug1: Applying options for *
debug1: Connecting to bitbucket.org [2406:da00:ff00::6b17:d1f5] port 22.
debug1: Connection established.
debug1: identity file /home/mrbig/.ssh/identity type -1
debug1: identity file /home/mrbig/.ssh/id_rsa type -1
debug1: identity file /home/mrbig/.ssh/id_dsa type 2
debug1: Checking blacklist file /usr/share/ssh/blacklist.DSA-1024
debug1: Checking blacklist file /etc/ssh/blacklist.DSA-1024
debug1: Remote protocol version 2.0, remote software version conker_1.1.15-49a70a8 app-130
debug1: no match: conker_1.1.15-49a70a8 app-130
debug1: Enabling compatibility mode for protocol 2.0
debug1: Local version string SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_5.1p1 Debian-6
debug1: SSH2_MSG_KEXINIT sent
debug1: SSH2_MSG_KEXINIT received
debug1: kex: server->client arcfour128 hmac-sha1 none
debug1: kex: client->server arcfour128 hmac-sha1 none
debug1: sending SSH2_MSG_KEXDH_INIT
debug1: expecting SSH2_MSG_KEXDH_REPLY
debug1: Host 'bitbucket.org' is known and matches the RSA host key.
debug1: Found key in /home/mrbig/.ssh/known_hosts:276
debug1: ssh_rsa_verify: signature correct
debug1: SSH2_MSG_NEWKEYS sent
debug1: expecting SSH2_MSG_NEWKEYS
debug1: SSH2_MSG_NEWKEYS received
debug1: SSH2_MSG_SERVICE_REQUEST sent
debug1: SSH2_MSG_SERVICE_ACCEPT received
debug1: Authentications that can continue: publickey
debug1: Next authentication method: publickey
debug1: Offering public key: Private Key
Connection closed by 2406:da00:ff00::6b17:d1f5
{code}

Please not the connection closed at the end.

And this happens when I change the order of the keys:

{code}
#!bash
 mrbig@toodark:~ $ ssh-add -l
1024 a7:83:14:47:7b:a1:ae:45:6b:c9:be:01:5c:74:7d:20 Private Key (RSA1)
2048 9c:53:e4:1b:07:9d:b6:50:cc:4a:09:a4:41:f5:93:5a .ssh/id_rsa_bitbucket (RSA)
1024 c6:f4:4b:b9:64:59:00:1a:fd:3c:ea:0a:fe:dd:4f:0a Private Key (RSA)
mrbig@toodark:~ $ ssh -v -T git@bitbucket.org
OpenSSH_5.1p1 Debian-6, OpenSSL 0.9.8m 25 Feb 2010
debug1: Reading configuration data /home/mrbig/.ssh/config
debug1: Applying options for *
debug1: Reading configuration data /etc/ssh/ssh_config
debug1: Applying options for *
debug1: Connecting to bitbucket.org [2406:da00:ff00::6b17:d1f5] port 22.
debug1: Connection established.
debug1: identity file /home/mrbig/.ssh/identity type -1
debug1: identity file /home/mrbig/.ssh/id_rsa type -1
debug1: identity file /home/mrbig/.ssh/id_dsa type 2
debug1: Checking blacklist file /usr/share/ssh/blacklist.DSA-1024
debug1: Checking blacklist file /etc/ssh/blacklist.DSA-1024
debug1: Remote protocol version 2.0, remote software version conker_1.1.15-49a70a8 app-126
debug1: no match: conker_1.1.15-49a70a8 app-126
debug1: Enabling compatibility mode for protocol 2.0
debug1: Local version string SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_5.1p1 Debian-6
debug1: SSH2_MSG_KEXINIT sent
debug1: SSH2_MSG_KEXINIT received
debug1: kex: server->client arcfour128 hmac-sha1 none
debug1: kex: client->server arcfour128 hmac-sha1 none
debug1: sending SSH2_MSG_KEXDH_INIT
debug1: expecting SSH2_MSG_KEXDH_REPLY
debug1: Host 'bitbucket.org' is known and matches the RSA host key.
debug1: Found key in /home/mrbig/.ssh/known_hosts:276
debug1: ssh_rsa_verify: signature correct
debug1: SSH2_MSG_NEWKEYS sent
debug1: expecting SSH2_MSG_NEWKEYS
debug1: SSH2_MSG_NEWKEYS received
debug1: SSH2_MSG_SERVICE_REQUEST sent
debug1: SSH2_MSG_SERVICE_ACCEPT received
debug1: Authentications that can continue: publickey
debug1: Next authentication method: publickey
debug1: Offering public key: .ssh/id_rsa_bitbucket
debug1: Server accepts key: pkalg ssh-rsa blen 277
debug1: Authentication succeeded (publickey).
debug1: channel 0: new [client-session]
debug1: Entering interactive session.
debug1: Requesting X11 forwarding with authentication spoofing.
debug1: Requesting authentication agent forwarding.
debug1: Sending environment.
debug1: Sending env LC_CTYPE = hu_HU.UTF-8
debug1: client_input_channel_req: channel 0 rtype exit-status reply 0
logged in as mr_big.

You can use git or hg to connect to Bitbucket. Shell access is disabled.
debug1: channel 0: free: client-session, nchannels 1
Transferred: sent 2400, received 2080 bytes, in 0.2 seconds
Bytes per second: sent 10781.1, received 9343.7
debug1: Exit status 0
{code}

And this is what happens when I offer a not registered 2048bit rsa key first:

{code}
#!bash
mrbig@toodark:~ $ ssh-add -l
2048 78:7b:96:e9:e3:be:71:48:dc:3b:b8:fe:27:80:b6:d4 .ssh/id_rsa_unkown (RSA)
2048 9c:53:e4:1b:07:9d:b6:50:cc:4a:09:a4:41:f5:93:5a .ssh/id_rsa_bitbucket (RSA)
mrbig@toodark:~ $ ssh -v -T git@bitbucket.org
OpenSSH_5.1p1 Debian-6, OpenSSL 0.9.8m 25 Feb 2010
debug1: Reading configuration data /home/mrbig/.ssh/config
debug1: Applying options for *
debug1: Reading configuration data /etc/ssh/ssh_config
debug1: Applying options for *
debug1: Connecting to bitbucket.org [2406:da00:ff00::22c0:3470] port 22.
debug1: Connection established.
debug1: identity file /home/mrbig/.ssh/identity type -1
debug1: identity file /home/mrbig/.ssh/id_rsa type -1
debug1: identity file /home/mrbig/.ssh/id_dsa type 2
debug1: Checking blacklist file /usr/share/ssh/blacklist.DSA-1024
debug1: Checking blacklist file /etc/ssh/blacklist.DSA-1024
debug1: Remote protocol version 2.0, remote software version conker_1.1.15-49a70a8 app-154
debug1: no match: conker_1.1.15-49a70a8 app-154
debug1: Enabling compatibility mode for protocol 2.0
debug1: Local version string SSH-2.0-OpenSSH_5.1p1 Debian-6
debug1: SSH2_MSG_KEXINIT sent
debug1: SSH2_MSG_KEXINIT received
debug1: kex: server->client arcfour128 hmac-sha1 none
debug1: kex: client->server arcfour128 hmac-sha1 none
debug1: sending SSH2_MSG_KEXDH_INIT
debug1: expecting SSH2_MSG_KEXDH_REPLY
debug1: Host 'bitbucket.org' is known and matches the RSA host key.
debug1: Found key in /home/mrbig/.ssh/known_hosts:276
debug1: ssh_rsa_verify: signature correct
debug1: SSH2_MSG_NEWKEYS sent
debug1: expecting SSH2_MSG_NEWKEYS
debug1: SSH2_MSG_NEWKEYS received
debug1: SSH2_MSG_SERVICE_REQUEST sent
debug1: SSH2_MSG_SERVICE_ACCEPT received
debug1: Authentications that can continue: publickey
debug1: Next authentication method: publickey
debug1: Offering public key: .ssh/id_rsa_unkown
debug1: Authentications that can continue: publickey
debug1: Offering public key: .ssh/id_rsa_bitbucket
debug1: Server accepts key: pkalg ssh-rsa blen 277
debug1: Authentication succeeded (publickey).
debug1: channel 0: new [client-session]
debug1: Entering interactive session.
debug1: Requesting X11 forwarding with authentication spoofing.
debug1: Requesting authentication agent forwarding.
debug1: Sending environment.
debug1: Sending env LC_CTYPE = hu_HU.UTF-8
debug1: client_input_channel_req: channel 0 rtype exit-status reply 0
logged in as mr_big.

You can use git or hg to connect to Bitbucket. Shell access is disabled.
debug1: channel 0: free: client-session, nchannels 1
Transferred: sent 2744, received 2112 bytes, in 0.2 seconds
Bytes per second: sent 12529.5, received 9643.7
debug1: Exit status 0
{code}

As you can see in this case the unregistered key is simply rejectet but the connection is not closed by the server.

#Expected behavior

The server should reject the unsupported rsa key as if it would not been known. This would allow the authentication process to continue with the next key.
fields.summary: Unsupported RSA key causes connection close

fields.description:
As the title says, when creating a new branch with the exact same name as an existing one on a repo, an error message like this pops up:

"We couldn't create a branch"\\
"If this keeps happening, talk to a repository admin"

It would be better to have a more fitting error message in this case, as it would lead the user to fix their issue much faster.

fields.description:

Attached you can see a few screenshots of a schedule pipeline where:

* I selected it to run every Friday between 01:00 and 02:00 (this is what I want, my timezone - *BRT*)
* It says it is going to run every Friday between  04:00 and 05:00  (it is probably what I want but displaying using *UTC*. For my use cases it is irrelevant but OK)
* After saved, UI displays it will run every Thursday at 01:AM (I have no idea about what timezone is being used here but it is deftly none of the above two)

Thanks

fields.description:
Hi,

Recently my bitbucket repository stopped show Ahead/Behind count of all branches within a repository. Please help.

Regards,

Mukesh

 

To expand on the exhibited behavior: 

due to the asynchronous tasks that run in the background to do the calculation for branches ahead/behind to identify Active branches , Bitbucket will show all branches merged/closed under Active view, which can be misleading.

Workaround: 

Refreshing the browser once normally resolves the issue. 
In case it is necessary for you to raise a Pull Request, use the Pull Request section instead of the "Branch" section.
fields.summary: Ahead/Behind of branches not showing

fields.description:
Reported by a vendor:

bq. I need to check if a given user (knowing its uuid) is an admin of the account where our application was installed. To do that, I'm calling:

/2.0/teams/<team uuid>/permissions?q=user.uuid="<user uuid>" AND permission = "admin"

It was not working until I realized that the uuid passed in the BBQL query should not have its curly braces (while this is required in the URL path segments).

This works:\\
/2.0/teams/{32c9b1aa-ff23-4a90-b5c7-bd5a3036a3e8}/permissions?q=user.uuid%3D%22ac49ff0d-4d0d-4bde-b78e-993ecf35db42%22%20AND%20permission%3D%22admin%\\
22

This doesn't:\\
/2.0/teams/{32c9b1aa-ff23-4a90-b5c7-bd5a3036a3e8}/permissions?q=user.uuid%3D%22%7Bac49ff0d-4d0d-4bde-b78e-993ecf35db42%7D%22%20and%20permission%3D%22\\
admin%22

Is it the expected behavior? Can I rely on this to continue working the same in the future? > Or is it a bug that may eventually be fixed and then will break our integration?
fields.summary: BBQL on permissions API should accept user UUIDs with curlies

fields.summary: Git Fetch Not Working

fields.description:
Since Bitbucket is limited to 2 GB repositories, it is important to manage the repository's file size. Binaries (especially large ones) should be excluded. Package managers should be used.

But mistakes happen. Binaries get checked in by accident. Old projects have dependencies checked in from before a language's package manager became popular, and they can't be easily removed without breaking the project on those commits. Dependencies aren't available via package manager, or a custom build with source code modification was checked in and there isn't time/budget to fix that right now.

BitBucket's interface makes dealing with these situations difficult. The garbage collection happens completely transparently; I can't even tell when it last completed. I have no idea what options it ran with. I don't even know which commands were invoked. Even once you've corrected a mistake and deleted some binary from the repository (including historical commits), it can still linger in the internal storage files for some time, maybe forever if the right clean up commands are never invoked.

git provides a number of useful commands for cleaning up garbage from the repository:

* {{git gc}}
* {{git gc --aggressive}}
* {{git repack}}  (with arguments)
* {{git prune}}

Some of them are discussed in more detail [here|https://stackoverflow.com/q/28720151/].

BitBucket provides no useful interface for invoking these or understanding what has been invoked on the repository. BitBucket does not need to provide direct access to the repository on the server, of course, but the available tooling needs some serious improvement.

# Be more transparent. The admin interface should tell me when a garbage collection was last completed and should tell me what command it was. It should tell me when the next one is scheduled to run under normal circumstances. It doesn't have to name the full command, but some kind of indication would be helpful.
# Ideally, I could tell the system to invoke one immediately when I think it's needed. Having limitations on this to prevent abuse would be fine.
# There should be some kind of option(s) to cause the system to invoke more aggressive clean up efforts, like {{git gc --aggressive}} or maybe some form of {{git repack}}. These would be _especially_ useful for mistakes that happened recently and can be cleaned up by modifying recent history. Even if I can't invoke one manually, I could tell the system to be more aggressive on the next attempt.
fields.summary: Improve options for managing repository size

fields.description:
I think all sorts of updates would be great to have in real-time, but the primary one is comments. Currently, when discussing a pull request with a fellow user on Bitbucket, you have to reload the page in order for their new comments to load. This is a pretty awful user experience, since there may be several comments generated in one discussion. If they make a new comment while you are typing, you'll miss out on new, possibly relevant information until you manually reload the page!

Real-time updates would also be much appreciated on the "view all PRs" page. For instance, if one of my pull requests was merged, I'll have to refresh the page page to see that that it got merged.

Of course, this is not an issue if you're coming to the page for a brief, one-time visit, but I often have the PR page open in the browser as I work, since we try to move quickly on those. It's tough to use it like a modern web app without real-time updates.
fields.summary: Updates to pull requests (especially comments) should display in real-time

fields.description:
@jxadamb can you please share an example of your XML file here. I'll then add it to the description.

Current the test report parser only reads success/failed/error from the attributes on an XML nodes. However, some tools (such as tslint) using a node to report the status of the test <testsuites><testcase><failure>.

{code}
#!
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<testsuites package="tslint">
  <testsuite name="lib/__tests__/get-parameters.test.ts">
    <testcase name="Line 9, Column 5: object-literal-sort-keys">
    <failure type="error">The key 'region' is not sorted alphabetically</failure>
    </testcase>
  </testsuite>
  <testsuite name="lib/get-parameters.ts">
    <testcase name="Line 34, Column 5: object-literal-sort-keys">
    <failure type="error">The key 'names' is not sorted alphabetically</failure>
    </testcase>
  </testsuite>
</testsuites>
{code}
fields.summary: Support parsing XML nodes for Test Reporting results

fields.description:
Hi,

I'm using TSLint to generate a Junit XML file to be reported on by Pipelines.

However, when I run my builds and the XML I've attached to this ticket gets generated in a folder called 'test-reports', I get the following messaging from Pipelines:

_Searching for test report files in directories named [test-results, failsafe-reports, test-reports, surefire-reports] down to a depth of 4\\
Found matching test report file /opt/atlassian/pipelines/agent/build/test-reports/lint.xml\\
Located test suite containing 0 tests, with 0 failures and 0 errors.\\
Located test suite containing 0 tests, with 0 failures and 0 errors.\\
Finished scanning for test reports. Found 1 test report files.\\
Merged test suites, total number tests is 0, with 0 failures and 0 errors._

Pipelines appears to be locating the file correctly and it's even managed to determine that there are two test suites. However, it doesn't appear to have noticed that there are some tests in these suites and some of them are failing (as per the XML).

The only difference I've found between this Junit XML output by TSLint and that of something like a Jest JUnit output is that this is missing some attributes (such as success/failure). However, I would have thought that Pipelines would have been able to infer these figures from the hierarchy?
fields.summary: Junit tests not being parsed

fields.description: You can no longer create tasks from comments on a pull request when you use the new UI for pull requests.

*Expected behavior:*

fields.description:
I am getting 429 errors while trying to check on files using bitbucket cloud thru my browser.

I dont want to checkout code everytime I want to check on something, please fix
fields.summary: Getting 429 errors while navigating code on the browser

fields.description:
On the new Bitbucket UI, sometimes the markdown breaks the text at the incorrect place.\\
Most of the time, the text is displayed like this, without breaking the line, which is correct:\\
!751682933-Screen%20Shot%202018-10-17%20at%2014.13.05.png|thumbnail!

However, sometimes it breaks the text in the middle of the page, like this\\
!3558784071-Screen%20Shot%202018-10-17%20at%2014.13.18.png|thumbnail!

I don't have a specific scenario to reproduce this (this seems to be quite intermittent), but I can assure that those two files I compared above are identical.
fields.summary: Markdown on the new UI sometimes breaks lines incorrectly
